docs.lead_paragraph: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. In the summer of 1978, when a day-care program was set up in the downtown Y.W.C.A. for the children of the chemically contaminated Love Canal neighborhood, the director of the program, Linda Forster, thought that many of them seemed "shy, disoriented, bitter toward Hooker Chemical Company and the chemical industry in general."

headline.main: Love Canal Is Extra Tough on Children; Love Canal Is Especially Tough on the Children Who Still Live There 'I Can't Do Anything at All' Other Factors Are Cited

docs.abstract: Children in Love Canal area reportedly are suffering stress and strain following finding of chemical contaminants in neighborhood; most children mirror fears and concern of parents; 2 teenage girls have committed suicide; Linda Forster, who runs day-care program, John Lynch of Catholic Charities and Dr James Dunlop, pediatrician, comment; illustration of Dunlop with young patients (L)
docs.snippet: NIAGARA FALLS, N.Y. In the summer of 1978, when a day-care program was set up in the downtown Y.W.C.A. for the children of the chemically contaminated Love Canal neighborhood, the director of the program, Linda Forster, thought that many of them...

byline.original: By DUDLEY CLENDINEN Special to The New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: In the summer of 1978, when a day-care program was set up in the downtown Y.W.C.A. for the children of the chemically contaminated Love Canal neighborhood, the director of the program, Linda Forster, thought that many of them seemed ''shy, disoriented, bitter toward Hooker Chemical Company and the chemical industry in general.'' Last summer, as earthmovers worked to clear the chemical waste that had been dumped by Hooker years ago, the day-care center was opened again, this time for preschool children.

headline.main: LOVE CANAL IS EXTRA TOUGH ON CHILDREN
